title: Data sources
content:
Searching for data (Googling)

Search by file type by adding to your search


  look only for spreadsheets filetype:XLS filetype:CSV
  look for geodata filetype:shp
  look for database extracts filetype:MDB, filetype:SQL, filetype:DB
  look for PDF files filetype:pdf


Search by part of a URL


  inurl:downloads filetype:xls will try to find all Excel files that have ‚Äúdownloads‚Äù in their web address
  site:agency.gov to limit your search to only those results on a single domain name


Search for bulk data


  site:agency.gov Directory Listing may give you some listings generated by the web server with easy access to raw files


More on finding data / advanced Googling


  üîó ProPublica‚Äôs slide dek ‚ÄúWhere to find data‚Äù
  üîó Learno‚Äôs Google search for journalists
  üîó Full list of advanced search operators


Basic web scrapping


  Use existing function in Google Spreadsheets or Excel to import data
    
      IMPORTXML: Imports data from any of various structured data types including XML, HTML, CSV, TSV, and RSS and ATOM XML feeds.
      IMPORTRANGE: Imports a range of cells from a specified spreadsheet.
      IMPORTFEED: Imports a RSS or ATOM feed.
      IMPORTDATA: Imports data at a given url in .csv (comma-separated value) or .tsv (tab-separated value) format.
    
  


=IMPORTHTML("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_lakes_of_Ontario", "table", 1)
=IMPORTHTML(URL, query, index)

Step-by-step explanation

Step 1. Find the data (in a table, url with .csv/.tsv, RSS feed, or XML). Check that data is available as an HTML table (check using Developer Tools); make note of the number of tables on the page. Grab the URL of the webpage.



Step 2. In a blank Google Spreadsheet, in cell A1 (top left cell), insert a IMPORTHTML function, supplying the URL, query, and index
	- URL: where you are retrieving the data from
	- query: what you are retrieving from the webpage
	- index: which number of the query you are retrieving (ie., if there are 3 tables on a page, specify which table you need)



Step 3. This data is connected to the live data (ie., the webpage). To sort the data, or create a Pivot Table, be sure to copy the table and, in a new table, use Paste special to paste the table data. OR download the data as a CSV (File > Download as > Comma-separated values) then import into a new sheet (File > Import) ‚Äî use this option for large datasets, or datasets with a lot of numbers (especially dates as these numbers will often be truncated when using copy/paste).



More on importing data

  Google Spreadsheet support docs
  Importing JSON


Pulling data from the Network tab

What is the Network tab?
- a tab in Developer Tools that allows us to look at requests being made on a page
- Developer Tools records all network requests in the Network panel
	- we can look JavaScript/CSS files loading in the webpage

Step-by-step explanation


  Using the Network tab  to extract every incident noted on this Vision Zero map


Step 1: Open Developer Tools (right-click + inspect, or View > Developer > View Source)
	* refresh the page (command + R)



Step 2: Look at XHR - this section contains all XHR/fetch requests being made (ie., to get JSON data)
	* click the query in the Name section
	* look at the request
		* Headers: headers sent with the request for data
		* Preview: what comes back (expand Features)
		* Response: raw data
		* Timing: how long it took



Step 3: Copy + paste into a formatter to make human-readable).


  save as JSON
  convert to CSV




More on the network tab

  üîó Google support docs


Data sites and services (an incomplete list)

Canadian data

  Toronto
    
      Toronto‚Äôs Open Data Catalogue
        
          data/maps kept by the city
          data: 311 calls, 911 calls, restaurant inspections, subway outages, parking tickets, etc.
          example:
            
              Basement flooding by ward
              what: service requests by ward due to basement flooding
              how much: 12 years of data for all 42 wards
              available as: CSV/Excel sheet
            
          
        
      
      Public Safety Data Portal
        
          data: major crime, homicide, traffic signal, fatal collisions, etc.
          maps: crime, service calls, etc
        
      
      City of Toronto‚Äôs Lobbying Registry
        
          names of every lobbyist at City Hall
          search functionality
        
      
      Councillor‚Äôs Business Expenses
        
          Toronto city council expenses by councillor since 2013
          available as table(s)
          Constituency office expenses since 2013
          council general expense
          council travel expense
        
      
    
  
  Ontario
    
      Open Data Portal
        
          government data
          example:
            
              Government of Ontario art collection
              what: basic information about the Ontario government‚Äôs art collection, dates back to 1853
              how much: ~2,700 original works of art
              available as: CSV
            
          
        
      
      Registry of lobbyists
        
          searchable database of active/inactive lobbyists at Queen‚Äôs Park
        
      
      Sunshine List
        
          all public sector employees who were paid $100,000+
        
      
      Elections Ontario
        
          names of those who made contributions to political parties
        
      
    
  
  Federal (Canada)
    
      Open Government Portal
      75,000+ datasets tied to various ministries/agencies
        
          example:
            
              Art Bank Collection
              what: contemporary Canadian art
              how much: 17,000 paintings, prints, photographs and sculptures by some 3,000 artists
              available as: XML
            
          
        
      
      Statistics Canada
        
          Census data
          The Daily
          StatsCannabis: user-generated data on cannabis prices across the country
        
      
      Trade data online
        
          statistics on international trade
        
      
      Transportation Safety Board
        
          every plane, train or boat accident or incident
        
      
      The Registry of Lobbyists
        
          lobbyists in Ottawa
        
      
      Recall and safety alerts database
        
          searchable database of recalls
        
      
      Government-tendered contracts
        
          All contracts awarded by the Canadian government and how much they cost
        
      
      Canlii
        
          searchable databases of lawsuit filed in Canada
          available by province
        
      
      Bankruptcy and Insolvency
    
  





And also:

  Creating or collecting data yourself
    
      crowd-sourcing
      live data (social media analytics)
      web scrapping
      ATIPs
      leaks/data dumps
      FOIs, etc.
    
  


More on data

  üîó Data Journalism Handbook

title: Checking data
content:
Checking data

Download all the data used in these examples: data_working_with_data.zip

A quick scan of the dataset ‚Äì


  
    
      Questions to ask your data
    
  
  
    
      Are there missing or truncated values?
    
    
      Are there out of range values?
    
    
      Look at all the values that appear in a column/row ‚Äì do they make sense?
    
    
      Are there similar repeated values?
    
    
      Is the data format what you would expect for the data type?
    
    
      How was the data collected? Is it from a survey (survey ‚Äì online survey vs. phone calls)?
    
    
      How was the data verified? If data is entered by hand by a human person, how was it verified?
    
    
      When was the data collected?
    
    
      What is the gap between being collected and published? ie., there will always be a lag between when census data is collected from Canadians and when it is made available (to download/access)
    
  


Check for skewed data


  Inflation
  Currency inflation means that over time money changes in value
  Check with the source of the data to see if the numbers are adjusted
  How to correct Adjust the numbers for inflation (for example: using the Bank of Canada‚Äôs inflation calculator )



  
    
      Example
      What does it look like
    
  
  
    
      Housing prices since the 1950s Wow! Homes got expensive! Adjusted for inflation, the 1950 home was $44,600. Still a big spike, but less drastic (and other factors, like the size of homes changing, can help explain this change).
      
    
  


median_housing_price.csv


  Seasonal variation
  Many types of data fluctuate naturally due to some underlying forces.
    
      for example: employment fluctuating with the seasons (ie., around the Christmas season, or summer months)
      check if the data has been ‚Äúseasonally adjusted‚Äù
    
  
  Timeframe or frame of reference has been manipulated



  
    
      Example
      What does it look like
    
  
  
    
      MTV‚Äôs Teen Mom vs. teen birth rate Teen Mom aired its first season in the summer of 2009. The following year the teen birth rate dropped 3.6%, and the rate continued to drop every year following ‚Äî is an MTV reality television to thank for this drop in teen pregnancy? What was the historical trend?
      
    
  


teen_pregnancy.csv

Check for missing values or zeros/arbitrary values replace missing values


  Blank / ‚Äúnull‚Äù values
    
      Check for blank or ‚Äúnull‚Äù values
      Confirm what blank or ‚Äúnull‚Äù values mean (ie., is the value unavailable, missing, etc.)
      Data is missing
        
          ie., if a dataset is supposed to be about ‚ÄúCanada,‚Äù check that all 10 provinces and 3 territories are reflected in the data
          do a first pass on a dataset to make sure the data provided matches what you expected
        
      
    
  
  When in doubt: Go back to the source of the data to confirm why a value is missing, zero (0), or null



  
    
      Example
      What does it look like
    
  
  
    
      2018 Toronto condo sales date If a data set is to represent a full year, check that all months are recorded
      
    
  


Check for units, categories, and labels


  Currency
    
      Check if foreign prices may be specified in their local currency
        
          ie., is you data in USD or CAD? üîó RBC calculator
        
      
      What year is the dollar value from
        
          ie., a $100 in 2010 is not $100 in 2019
          Check and adjust for inflation üîó Bank of Canada calculator
        
      
    
  
  Categories
    
      Bad categories can artificially exclude data.
      For example: crime statistics. A bad or changing definition might mean a crime is counted in a different category than you expect or that it wasn‚Äôt counted at all.
    
  
  Labels
    
      Ambiguity = a likely error
      Confirm with the source of the dataset your understanding matches their definitions
  
    
  



  
    
      Example
      What does it look like
    
  
  
    
      Column labels are too broad or unclear Both earnings and dollars are bad column headers. Once you divide the dollars value by the shows_played_2101 value, it is clear that dollars refers to total earnings for the complete tour in 2018. The headers should be updated to reflect the content (the total per tour earning, and the per show earnings).
      
    
  


highest_grossing_tours_2018.csv

Check for inconsistencies


  Spelling is inconsistent
    
      Check that location/place names are consistent
        
          ie., Los Angelos instead of Los Angeles
        
      
      Check locations for inconsistent spelling, or inconsistent short forms/abbreviations
        
          ie., both Sault Sainte. Marie and Sault Ste. Marie
        
      
      Often indicates that the data was compiled by a human person, reason to be skeptical of the data
      You will need to manually correct mistakes or otherwise account for them in your analysis and reporting
      Be sure to document your changes
    
  



  
    
      Example
      What does it look like
    
  
  
    
      Inconsistent place names Here are three options for a city in Ontario. Which is correct?
      
    
  


place_names.csv


  Name order is inconsistent
    
      Check that first_name and last_name are accurately reflect the content
    
  



  
    
      Example
      What does it look like
    
  
  
    
      Checking names Can you spot the celebrity whose name is incorrectly entered?
      
    
  


names.csv


  Date formats are inconsistent
    
      Check that all dates are day/month/year or month/day/year
      Check that dates use consistent year formats (ie., 2015 vs 15)
        
          ie., both 10/9/15 and 9/10/15 are valid date formats, but are they the same date?
        
      
      Where did the data originate? (European vs. American date formats). If you are unsure, check with the source.
    
  



  
    
      Example
      What does it look like
    
  
  
    
      Checking dates There are four different dates formats here. If the data was collected in Canada, which format should be used?
      
    
  


date_formats.csv

Check for numbers as text and text as numbers

  Not all numerals are numbers
  Spreadsheets programs often make the mistake of assuming numerals are numbers and stripping the leading zeros.
    
      ie., New England zip codes almost always start with zero, i.e. 02901
      Excel assumes it‚Äôs numeric and ‚Äúhelpfully‚Äù drops that leading zero, making the value inaccurate
    
  
  Good practice is to store numbers without formatting and to include supporting information in column names or metadata.



  
    
      Example
      What does it look like
    
  
  
    
      Checking numberical values It looks like some of these number values are formatted incorrectly ‚Äî check that it is a formatting error (and not something else)
      
    
  


Zeros replace missing values / data is missing

  If you see zeros in a series of numbers you should ask yourself if those values are really the number 0 or if they instead mean "nothing". (-1 is also sometimes used this way.)



  
    
      Example
      What does it look like
    
  
  
    
      Checking for zeros Did Bruno Mars really make millions of dollars playing a negative number of shows?
      
    
  


Check number of columns and rows

  Excel has (had) a maximum of 65,536 rows. If your dataset has 65,536 rows, you likely have a portion of the data. Go back to the source to confirm or request the full dataset.
  Apple‚Äôs Numbers can only handle 255 columns. If 255 rows, you might only have a portion of the data. Go back to the source to confirm or request the full dataset.


Check for these suspicious values
If you see any of these values in your data, treat them with an abundance of caution:

Numbers:


  65,535
  255
  2,147,483,647
  4,294,967,295
  555-3485
  99999 (or any other long sequence of 9‚Äôs)
  00000 (or any other sequence of 0‚Äôs)


Dates:


  1970-01-01T00:00:00Z
  1969-12-31T23:59:59Z
  January 1st, 1900
  January 1st, 1904


Spreadsheet has dates in 1900, 1904, 1969, or 1970

Excel‚Äôs default date from which it counts all other dates is January 1st, 1900, unless you‚Äôre using Excel on a Mac, in which case it‚Äôs January 1st, 1904. There are a variety of ways in which data in Excel can be entered or calculated incorrectly and end up as one of these two dates. If you spot them in your data, it‚Äôs probably an issue.

Many databases and applications will often generate a date of 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z or 1969-12-31T23:59:59Z which is the Unix epoch for timestamps. In other words this is what happens when a system tries to display an empty value or a 0 value as a date.

Locations:


  0¬∞00'00.0"N+0¬∞00'00.0"E or simply 0¬∞N 0¬∞E
  US zip code 12345 (Schenectady, New York)
  US zip code 90210 (Beverly Hills, CA)


Each of these numbers has an indication of a particular error made by either a human or a computer. If you see them, ensure they actually mean what you think they mean!

Note: Many of these tips are pulled from Quartz‚Äôs Bad Data Guide.

More on checking data


  üîó Quartz‚Äôs full Bad Data Guide
  üîó ProPublica‚Äôs Bulletproofing Your Data Guide




Homework:

Create an account on Learno.

Complete module 1 and 2 from Cleaning data in Excel. Feel free to use Google Spreadsheets when working with the data.

title: Introduction to visualizing data
content:
Tools for visualizing data



  DataWrapper
  Google Charts


Create an account for DataWrapper.

Using charts

As a reporting tool, charts are useful to:


  Identify themes or trends in the data
    
      helps identify a ‚Äútypical‚Äù example
    
  
  Identify questions to answer in the rest of your reporting
  Quickly understand the data or find questions answer
    
      ie., a quick bar chart can show the distribution of data
    
  
  Show outliers in the data
    
      sometimes this could be a story lead to pursue
      sometimes this could be a hole or error in the data
    
  


As a visual element (for readers), charts are useful to:


  Highlight/reinforce the key point of a story
  Show trends over time
  Make/show comparisons
    
      better/ worse than
    
  
  Show relationships
    
      correlations between variables
    
  
  Show the movement or flow of data
    
      how data points move between groups
    
  
  Show an outliers in the data
  Can allow you to remove paragraphs of numbers from a story


Chart types

Basic/common charts:

üìä Bar/column charts:


  Best for discrete units of measurement
  Each bar is used to show discrete, numerical comparisons amongst categories
  One axis shows value scale, other shows categories compared
    
      Axis always starts at zero
    
  



View chart

Multiline bar/column charts:


  Multi-set or stacked
  Useful alternative to pie charts
  Bars of multiple datasets stacked on top of each other
  Simple Stacked Bar Graphs: adds each segment of data in a row
  100% Stack Bar Graphs: adds each proportional segment of data in a row; adds up to 100%
    
      use this as an alternative to pie charts
    
  



Facebook active users chart

üìà Line charts


  Best for showing a continuous value/set of values
    
      Show trends, analyze how data changes over time
    
  
  Slope of the line between two points shows change pattern
  Plot a point on X / Y axis, connect each point with a line
    
      Y axis: quantitative
      X axis: time/sequential (ie., dates)
    
  
  X axis does not necessarily have to start at zero


Single line charts


  Show change of one variable/category over time
  Good for: prices (stocks, housing/rent, )



Tilray stock

Multi-line chart


  Shows many lines (series)
  Should limit of 3-4 lines (more than that becomes difficult to read/understand)
  Or: show one line (highlighted colour) against many lines (grey/neutral colour)



Mid-term election explainer

Advanced charts:


  Area graph
  Scatterplot
    
      plot data points against two variables (on the X and Y axis)
      useful to see if a relationship (correlation) exists
      shows patterns or relationships
    
  
  Sankey
    
      flow diagram
      shows movement from one set of values to another
    
  
  Histograms


Charts to avoid

ü•ß Pie charts


  Show proportions or percentages of categories  
  Each slice of the pie (chart) represents a % of the total (100%)
  Pie chart cons:
    
      hard for readers to understand many data points (ie., very slim slices of pie)
      bad for comparison
    
  


Poor uses of the pie chart

 Link
 Link


  If you use a pie chart:
    
      use no more than 3 categories of data
      best option is to compare a part to the whole (‚Äúone against all others‚Äù)
    
  


A better use of the pie chart



  Alternative: Stacked Bar Graph
    
      use a bar chart/stacked bar chart
      square pie or waffle chart skip to: ‚ÄúAlternative: Squaring the Pie‚Äù
    
  


More on pie charts ü•ß

  üîó What to consider when creating pie charts
  üîó In defense of the pie chart
  üîó Understanding Pie Charts

  üîó The hate of pie charts harms good data visualization


When NOT use a chart


  When you have a very limited amount of data points
  When the data shows lot of fluctuation, or a flat trend
  When it could be a table


What information should you include in a chart

Information you must include


  Title
  Data source


Information you should include


  Formatting symbols
    
      $ for monetary values, % if value is a percentage, etc.
    
  


Optional information to include


  Sub-title
    
      Add when supplementary information is necessary
    
  
  X/Y axis labels
    
      Add labels when useful to provide additional context/information
    
  
  A legend: if you have data with categories
    
      Use to explain why a bar/line uses a specific colour
    
  


More on delivering data visualizations


  üîó Different Charts Tell Different Tales
  üîó Data Journalism Handbook


Review

  Which type of chart us best used to display or analyze trends over time?
    
      A line chart
    
  
  Why should you avoid pie charts?
    
      It is often difficult for a reader to understand how much each slice of the pie represents.
    
  
  What is a useful alternative to the pie chart?
    
      A stacked bar chart.
    
  
  True or false: The X axis of a bar chart does not need to start at zero.
    
      False. The X axis of a bar chart must start at zero to avoid misrepresenting the data.
    
  
  Which type of chart is best used to display numerical comparisons among categories?
    
      A bar chart
    
  
  Which (advanced chart) can be used to determine if a relationship (correlation) exists between many data points?
    
      A scatterplot chart

title: What is a spreadsheet
content:
Spreadsheet basics

üíª Working with spreadsheets üíª

üëΩ üõ∏ To practice your spreadsheet skills, download this CSV: ufos.csv


  To follow along, open in Excel or Google Spreadsheets
    
      Download the CSV (remember where on your computer its saved!)
      Open Google Spreadsheets or Excel
      Import the file (File > Import)
      Make sure the spreadsheet/tab has a title
      Save the file (command + S on a Mac, control + S on a PC)
    
  





A spreadsheet


  A spreadsheet is a computer program
  Allows for simple or complex calculations on a series of numbers at the same time
  We use Excel or Google Spreadsheets to view and work with spreadsheets




A worksheet

  One page (or one ‚Äútab‚Äù)
  Grid of rows and columns
  Each ‚Äúworkbook‚Äù (the overall Excel/Google Spreadsheet file) can contain many worksheets


Rows

  Horizontal (width of page)
  Each row: a ‚Äúdata point‚Äù
  First row: ‚Äúheader row‚Äù which contains column labels




Columns


  Vertical (height of page)
  Contain ‚Äúvariables‚Äù or categories
    
      ie., each cell in the column contains ‚Äúdate‚Äù information
    
  




Cells


  Intersection of a column and a row
  Starts with A1 (upper left corner)
    
      ROW: 1
      COLUMN: A
    
  






Data types

Numerical


  Numeric/decimals
    
      counts, sums, dollars, dates/times
      Used for calculations
    
  


Formatting numerical values

  Numbers should be right-aligned
    
      Google/Excel might try to be helpful, and will often do this for you
      If ‚Äúnumber‚Äù is not right-aligned, check for error(s)
    
  





  Formatting options for numbers:
    
      As currency/money - ($)
      As percent (%)
      Change/adjust decimal(s) (rounding)
    
  




Text (‚Äústrings‚Äù)


  Names, addresses, descriptions, postal codes (anything that is not a number)
  Not used for calculations
    
      However, can use a function to split or concatenate text
      ie., merge several columns of data into a new column (ie., join text into an andress)
    
  
  Left aligned

title: Cleaning data
content:
Refer to previous lessons for checking data

Cleaning data: correcting the problems we check for

Note: Many of these tips are pulled from Quartz‚Äôs Bad Data Guide.

Fixing stuff

  TK


More on cleaning data


  üîó Learno‚Äôs Cleaning Data in Excel

title: Data visualization mistakes and how to fix them
content:
Common chart mistakes

Ordering data


  Your data should be sorted in a meaningful way:
    
      ordered values by most to least
      ordered by by year
    
  



  
    
      Example
      Chart (before/after)
    
  
  
    
      Order data by rental cost A bar chart about the cost of renting in cities across Canada should be ordered by the value (renting) instead of an alphabetical list of cities.
      
    
  


Labels become difficult to read


  Too many labels, or labels are too long
  How to fix
    
      Show fewer bars (top 10)
      Use horizontal version of the chart
      labels are on the Y axis (unless chart is a time series)
      Rotate labels to 45 deg
    
  



  
    
      Example
      Chart (before/after)
    
  
  
    
      Labels on the X axis vs. on the Y axis. In this bar chart, we transposed the data and reduced the number of cities being shown (only show 10 most expensive places)
      
    
  


Colour


  Use gradient colors to show a pattern (or range) in the data
    
      Light colors representing lower values
      Dark colors representing higher values
    
  
  No more than 5 colours
    
      If you have more than 5 colours (categories), regroup your data (or use an ‚Äúother‚Äù category to collect less significant categories)
      Use a legend to explain significance of colours (categories)
    
  
  One colour for all bars or one colour per category of data
  Make all bars a neutral colour (grey) and use secondary colour to highlight a specific bar
    
      üîó Example: Market capitalizations of select companies
    
  
  Ensure you are using high-contrast colour options



  
    
      Example
      Chart (before/after)
    
  
  
    
      Many colours vs. neturals Since each bar is a different colour, the colour choices do not communicate any additional information. We can replace the colours with one, neutral option.
      
    
  


Useless comparisons

  A comparison of absolute vs. proportional values
    
      ie., total number of births by province vs. birth rate by province (births per 1,000 women)
    
  
  Prices that are not adjusted for inflation
    
      $100 in 1981 != $100 in 2019
    
  


The baselines must accurately reflect the data

  Bar charts must always have a baseline of zero
  Line charts do not need to start at zero
    
      but be careful that you are not misrepresenting the data
    
  



  
    
      Example
      Chart
    
  
  
    
      A faulty baseline The baseline does not start at 0, wildly misrepresenting the data.
      
    
  


Misc.

  The math should make sense
    
      If you have a pie chart, do your slices add up to 100%?
    
  
  Label your axes
  Use a legend (to explain your colour choices/categories)
  Cite your sources
  Never make your chart 3D


Editing your charts

  We all make mistakes (this is why we have editors)
    
      When in doubt (even when confident!), ask for a second pair of eyes
    
  
  Walk someone else through your charts, they might catch assumptions or mistakes you missed


Let us avoid avoid embarrassing chart mistakes this inforgraphic from 2011 that breaks literally every rule ^^ above) A v. bad infographic

More on charting rules and best practices

  üîó What to consider when choosing colors for data visualization
  üîó Flowing Data - Chart Rules
  üîó Flowing Data - Useless Data Comparisons
  üîó Flowing Data - Bar Chart Baselines Start at Zero


Exercise

Bad charts

title: Spreadsheet basics
content:
‚ÄúPaste special‚Äù / ‚ÄúPaste transposed‚Äù

  ‚ÄúPaste special‚Äù: to paste values without special formatting
    
      when you execute a function in
      copy this data into a new
    
  
  see also: transpose functions (TK)


The header row

  The first row of data in a spreadsheet is usually reserved for column headers
  Labels that identify what content is in each column
    
      sometimes in short forms (ie., lat vs. latitude, AdvDeg vs. average_degree_score)
      when in doubt, check with the spreadsheet author
    
  
  For very long spreadsheets, useful to ‚Äúfreeze‚Äù the top row
    
      so you can view labels and values at the same time

    
  


How to ‚Äúfreeze‚Äù header row


  Ensure first row in the spreadsheet contains labels (if not: insert a row, add labels for each column)
  In Google Spreadsheets: Under View > Freeze > 1 row / 1 column

  In Excel: Under View > Freeze top row

  Scroll up/down and left/right with labels in view


Conditional formatting

  Useful way to highlight (colour-code) cells
    
      ie., show empty cells, or cells where the value is >= another value
    
  
  A range of colours
  A darker shade of red for UFO sightings with longer duration



A range of colours
- Turn cells black if the ‚ÄúColor‚Äù value is empty.


‚ÄúFreeze‚Äù header row


  Format > Conditional formatting ... > in the Conditional format rules editor, set rules for the selected cells
    
      Apply to range: the data to evaluate
      Format cell if: select the rule to evaluate
      Formatting style: select colour option
        
          single colour: ie., make all empty cells black
          color scale: ie., a range of colours reflecting values in a range
        
      
      Done: apply formatting
    
  


Creating a ‚Äúcounter‚Äù


  Create a ‚Äúcounter‚Äù
    
      Why: use this column to ‚Äúun-sort‚Äù the data
    
  
  How to:
    
      Insert new column, give it a name
      Define a pattern (1, 2, 3)
      Highlight cells with the pattern, drag or double-click to populate column

title: Tips for working with spreadsheets
content:
Spreadsheet üå∂ tips

Make a copy

Always, always, always: make a copy of your spreadsheet.

Always, always, always: work in the copy of your spreadsheet.

Always, always, always: Have a backup of your data.

Why? You will make mistakes and mess up a spreadsheet of information. You need to have a way to revert all your changes without affecting the integrity of the data.

Make it clear ~in the name of the file~ that you are working with a copy of your data. For example: ufo-sightings-COPY.csv and ufo-sightings-ORIGINAL.csv

Also be sure to save the original data on a USB, Google Drive, external hard-drive.

Your project folder should look something like this:


  containing project folder (my_data_project)
    
      a COPY of the original dataset (ufos_BACKUP.csv or ufos_COPY.csv)
      the Excel file with your analysis/changes (ufos.csv)
      a text file that outlines your workflow/documents your dataset (README.md - or a data dictionary)
    
  




Add permission settings

Add permissions/rules to the original so that only you can access it.

In Excel, you can add a password to a spreadsheet.

In Google Spreadsheets, you can add ‚Äúrules‚Äù to adjust settings by user.

Keep notes about your workflow, etc.

Create a text document for future reference. Keep notes about when the spreadsheet was last updated/edited (this is especially important for ongoing work or collaborative work).

For example: if you create a column for the result of a function/calculation, make a note of the column, the calculation, and the expected result.

Record a reference of short-forms/codes, etc. you use.

The Pudding‚Äôs README.md for their piece ‚ÄúInternet Boy Band Database‚Äù

Name: Jessie Willms
Contact: jwillms@email.com
Date: Jan. 14, 2019

Data: This spreadsheet contains UFO sightings that took place in Ontario in 2012.
The sightings were compiled from the website ufosightings.com.
The spreadsheet contains 101 rows and 17 columns.

Analysis: Created a Pivot Table to find the total number of "red" sightings that happened in the summer (May-August).

Process: I used this function to show sightings that were longer than 10 seconds: =IF(M4>10,1,0).

The function executes in column H (long_sightings), with a value of 1 when true, and 0 when false.



Why do this


  
    Current you: writing out your process provides an opportunity to proofread/double check your work
  
  
    Future you: you will likely forget exactly what you did; instead of guessing, you will have the steps you took, and know how to repeat it.
  


For example: Your original reporting about bicycle thefts in Toronto includes data for 2010 to 2017. In January 2019, Toronto Police release data for 2018. You should be able to repeat your initial analysis in January 2019. Ensure you have sufficient notes to make this possible.



  In addition:
  Someone else (a data editor) can check your work
  Another data reporter should be able to reproduce your results
  Use this information to share your methodology/process with experts/readers

title: Filtering, sorting, and functions
content:
Sorting


  
    Putting your data in an order (A-Z or Z-A)
  
  
    How to (Excel):
    
      Select the column
      In the ‚ÄúData‚Äù tab, click AZ, ZA, or the large Sort icon
      Ensure option ‚ÄúExpand the selection‚Äù is selected
      Click ‚ÄúSort‚Äù
    
  





  How to (Google Spreadsheets):
    
      Click small caraet on letter cell above header row
      From dropdown, select Sort sheet ‚ü∂ A-Z
    
  




Functions

What is a function?


  Goal is to create new information from existing data
  Functions performs operations on text + numbers
  For example
    
      Numbers:
        
          Calculating averages, sums (totals)
          Finding median, min, max, counts
          Rounding numbers, calculating time/ranges
        
      
      Strings (text):
        
          splitting data into multiple columns (YY-MM-DD to year, month, day),
          or concatenating (joining) text (city, province, country into one column)
        
      
    
  




Some common functions

Look at some of these functions in action:



Getting data
-Return x character(s) from the left or right of specific cell.
=LEFT(A2,1)
=RIGHT(A2,1)

Joining data


  
    Join text together (each cell separated by the delimiter, "-"):
=JOIN("-",D2,E2,F2)
  
  
    Concatenate/join text together (separated by specific text)
=CONCATENATE=(D2," and ", E2, "will be joined together with pal", F2)
  


Basic math


  
    Find sum (total) for specific values:
=SUM(A2, B2, C2)
  
  
    Find sum (total) for a range of values:
=SUM(A2:A100)
  
  
    Find the average of a specific values:
=AVERAGE(C2,C5,C10)
  
  
    Find average of a range of values:
=AVERAGE(C2:C100)
  
  Find the median value in a set of values
  
    Median: when a set of values is sorted,
=MEDIAN(C1:C101)
  
  
    Find the highest value(s)
=MAX(C1:C101)
  
  
    Find the lowest value(s)
=MIN(C1:C101)
  
  
    Do some simple math (addition, subtraction, multiplication)
=(C1 / C101)
=(C1 * C101)
=(C101 - C1)
=(C101 + C1)
  
  Calculate a date range
=DATEIF(136)


Checking data


  
    Checks one value if a logical expression is TRUE and another if it is FALSE:
=IF(A2 = "sunshine", "True: Nice weather", "False: Lousy weather")
=IF(A2 >= 12, 1, 0)
=IF( (A2 / 10 > 100), 1, 0)
  
  
    Returns the position at which a string is first found within text, case-sensitive:
=FIND("wood","How much wood can a woodchuck chuck")
  
  How it works:
  =FIND: name of the function
  (search_for, text_to_search, [starting_at]): inside the round brackets, we have two mandatory parameters, and one optional parameter
  search_for: the first parameter; the sub-string (text) to look for
  text_to_search: the second parameter; where to look
  
    [starting_at]: optional third parameter; what character to start looking
  
  Returns the position at which a string is first found within text, ignoring case.
SEARCH("wood","How much wood can a woodchuck chuck")
SEARCH(search_for, text_to_search, [starting_at])


Checking data types


  
    Checks if data is a string (text)
=ISTEXT("sunny weather")
=ISTEXT(8)
  
  
    Checks if data is a boolean (true/false) value
=ISLOGICAL(TRUE)
=ISLOGICAL(B12)
  
  
    Checks if data is a number
=ISNUMBER(136)
=ISNUMBER(B12)
  


Error handling


  
    Checks if a cell value is equal to an error (#N/A)
=ISNA(A2)
  
  
    Checks for an error in a specific cell
=IFERROR(A1,"Error in cell A1")
  


For more practice with functions, work through these problems 

Getting data


  
    Import a table of data from the internet
=IMPORTHTML("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_2018_box_office_number-one_films_in_the_United_States", "TABLE", 1)
=IMPORTHTML("https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/drugs-medication/cannabis/industry-licensees-applicants/licensed-cultivators-processors-sellers.html", "TABLE", 1)
=IMPORTHTML("https://www.billboard.com/archive/charts/1991/country-songs", "TABLE", 1)
  
  Import a table of data from the internet
=IMPORTHTML("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_2018_box_office_number-one_films_in_the_United_States", "TABLE", 1)
=IMPORTHTML("https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/drugs-medication/cannabis/industry-licensees-applicants/licensed-cultivators-processors-sellers.html", "TABLE", 1)
=IMPORTHTML("https://www.agco.ca/cannabis/list-ontario-municipalities-prohibiting-or-allowing-cannabis-retail-stores", "TABLE", 1)
  
    Important note: check for paginated data (see AGCO example above; this will only return the first 20 results)
  
  Import a list of data from the internet
=IMPORTHTML("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_2018_box_office_number-one_films_in_the_United_States", "list", 1)


To find the index of a table:

Open Developer Tools, copy & paste this function.:

var i = 1; [].forEach.call(document.getElementsByTagName("table"), function(x) { console.log(i++, x); });

This will return the index of each table on the page.




  Import a CSV or TSV from the internet
=IMPORTDATA("http://opendata.toronto.ca/building/green.roof.permits/greenroof.csv")





  Import a range of data from another tab/sheet
=IMPORTRANGE(spreadsheet_key, "tab_name!A3")
=IMPORTRANGE("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1X5vqyLf7itgF-b6QZRRoVLuHdlji3mqvTDdKBUy8jG4/edit#gid=1687373309", "ufos!A3")


To practice your IMPORT skills, open import

VLOOKUP

=VLOOKUP(search_key, range, index, [is_sorted])

VLOOKUP looks for a value in a column; then it returns a value from any cell in the same row.

search_key: value to find
range: two or more columns, to find the data
index - the column number from the range; you can return any value in that row

To practice your VLOOKUP skills, open vlookup

Wrapping functions


  In the multiple_functions tab
  we can wrap multiple functions together
=IF(NOT(ISERR(FIND( "Disney", C3, 1))), 1, 0)
  
    ^ this is 3 functions in one line; starting from the innermost function
  
  1 FIND( "Disney", C3, 1)): checks the string in cell C3 to see if the substring ‚ÄúDisney‚Äù exists
  if the substring exists, this will return the position of the substring(a number)
  
    if the substring does not exist, it will return an error #VALUE!
  
  2 ISERR(value): check if the value is an error
  in our example, it is checking if FIND( "Disney", C3, 1)) returns an error
  
    wrapping this in a NOT() function (makes the next step easier)
  
  3 =IF( F3 = TRUE, 1, 0): returns 1 or 0 if the cell contains an error
  use this value to find the total number of Disney movies


Breaking down functions




  
    = to start the function. This cell is where the new value will live.
  
  JOIN: the name of the function
    
      usually tells you what the function will ~do~
    
  
  (): opening and closing parentheses
    
      wrap around the guts of the function
      think of it as the container
      contains parameters (arguement)
    
  
  "-": the delimiter
    
      the text (character) between values
    
  
  D2,E2,F2: the values that are being joined
    
      note the reference (D2) to each individual cell
      if comma separated: individual cells
      if colon separated: range of cells
    
  


What should we expect to happen when we execute this function?



A full date in column G:



More on functions


  üîó List of Google Spreadsheet functions
  üîó List of Excel functions 


Filtering

Creating a ‚Äúfiltered‚Äù view (to find things)


  Exact or ‚Äúfuzzy‚Äù matches
  Show/find ranges (numbers/dates)
  Filter for specific information (numbers >= X value)


üå∂Ô∏è tip: don‚Äôt save the filter; make a copy of the filtered data to work with

More on filtering


  üîó Google‚Äôs ‚ÄúSort & filter your data‚Äù how-to


More on Spreadsheets


  üîó ProPublica‚Äôs Intro to Spreadsheets
  üîó ProPublica‚Äôs String functions
  üîó Learno‚Äôs Doing Journalism with Data ‚Äî Module 3: Finding story ideas with data analysis
  üîó Learno‚Äôs Cleaning data in Excel

title: Pivot Tables
content:
Pivot Tables


  Pivot Tables are super powerful
  
    They can be used to summarize and explore your data quickly, or expose missing/bad data
  
  Great for:
    
      Count by variables (group)
      Sum by group
      Average by group
      Maximum or minimum by group
  
    
  
  How to (Google Spreadsheets):
    
      Data > Pivot table
      Opens in a new tab, with the Pivot Table editor open
      Add/move rows, columns, values, filters
    
  




What‚Äôs happening here?

  Rows the grouping variable
  Values: the variables we want to summarize ‚Äì values in our table




In the Pivot Table editor (right-hand side):

  Data range: what data to get from your worksheet/tab
    
      ufo-sightings-ontario-2012!A1:S101
      gets data from the ufo-sightings-ontario-2012 tab
      only gets data in the cells from A1 (top left) to S101
    
  
  Rows: Drag fields here to create rows
    
      Placing more than one value with create ‚Äúnested‚Äù rows
    
  
  Columns: Drag fields here to create columns
    
      Placing more than one value will create ‚Äúnested‚Äù columns
    
  
  Values: Drag fields here to determine the data that is being evaluated
  Filters: Selectively view data based on particular values
    
      can remove missing data, or data in a range, data less/more than x
    
  


We can summarize data by:

  COUNTA: gets a tally of cells containing values (ie., how many cells in a column called ‚ÄúColor‚Äù have a value of ‚Äúred‚Äù)
  SUM: the total
  MIN/MAX: biggest/smallest values


How many sightings in the summer months were red, excluding sightings with fewer than 2 witnesses:



Using data from Pivot Tables

When you make a pivot table, it remains tethered to the underlying data you used to create it. If the data changes, your table changes. But: editing, sorting, filtering the data is annoying.


  Solution: copy + paste the table into a new tab
  Select table
  Copy table
  In a new tab, go to: Edit > Paste special > paste values only




This table is no longer attached to the data.

If the data changes, your pasted table WILL NOT automatically update. There is not longer a connection between the Pivot Table and the worksheet.

More on Pivot Tables


  üîóProPublica Pivot Table how-to guide
  üîóGoogle support forum for creating a Pivot Table
  üîóYouTube video demonstrating how to create a Pivot Table

Back in nhl_player_salaries Practise with functions

  Create a Pivot Table to find which team has the most highest paid players. Name the team, and how many of their player made the list.
  Create a Pivot Table that returns the totals for each position (ie., how many captains on on the list).

title: What is "data journalism"?
content:
Defining ‚Äúdata journalism‚Äù

‚ÄúData can be the source of data journalism, or it can be the tool with which the story is told, or it can be both. Like any source, it should be treated with skepticism; and like any tool, we should be conscious of how it can shape and restrict the stories that are created with it.‚Äù
‚Äî Paul Bradshaw, Birmingham City University

It is also:

  Journalism that is done with (informed by) data
  ‚ÄúComputer assisted reporting‚Äù
    
      ie., computer programs to help election outcomes
    
  
  A tool for reporting/storytelling.


Data journalism is NOT

  Just ‚Äúinterviewing‚Äù a spreadsheet
  An beat or expertise for only a select few in a newsroom
  Real people, experts and ‚Äúword‚Äù reporting are still extremely necessary components of data journalism.


What does data journalism look like

  Building tools to scrape/analyze data (Python)
  Using Excel (Google Sheets, etc.) to find averages, most/least common (of a variable), identify outliers
  Reading budgets, court documents, business filings
  Request data/records from governments
  Creating charts + maps  to look at data
  Making user-facing tools (ie., calculator) (JavaScript)
  and much more


Why data journalism

  Scoop city. Population: you.
  Answers big/small questions
  Find ‚Äúhidden‚Äù stories
  Provide context/understanding


Data journalism examples

  üîóData journalism examples


Review

  What is data journalism?
    
      A kind of journalism done with data
    
  
  What are some tools we can use to do data journalism?
    
      Excel, Google Spreadsheets, charting tools (DataWrapper, etc)

title: The "data" component of "data journalism"
content:
Discussion question üôã

  What is the ‚Äúdata‚Äù component of data journalism?
  Where do we find data?



5 basic question for your data


  What does this data represent? Is it a full or partial view? What cannot be answered by the data?
  Can we trust this data? (Do you trust the sourcing, method of collection ‚Äî why?)
  Is this data clean? What errors or omissions are possible?
  Is this data in a machine-readable format? If not (if it is not a CSV/spreadsheet) what are our next steps for extracting the information?
  What can be extracted from this data? How can this information inform our reporting?

title: Visualizing data ‚Äî identifying errors in bad charts
content:
Bad charts

Project requirements


  Download this folder of ‚Äúbad charts‚Äù bad_charts.zip This folder contains images of poorly executed charts, as well as the related data (in a CSV).
  For each chart, identify the 2 most important issues with the chart*
    
      For each issue, explain:
        
          What is the issue? (2 point)
          Why does this matter? How does it misrepresent or manipulate the data? (4 point)
          How might you (as a reporter/editor) correct the issue (bullet points are fine). You might also suggest an alternative to running the chart. (4 point)
        
      
    
  
  Make a copy of this Google doc to submit your answers. Fill out each table, then download the doc as a PDF (File > Download as > PDF). Upload your completed PDF to the folder on eCentennial.


* Identify the most important issues/errors with a chart. If a chart uses colours that are low contrast, does not have an X or Y axis label, and the data is not adjusted for inflation, it is up to you to select the most important issue with the chart. You would be expected to explain why it is necessary to adjust for inflation and use labels on the axis. Colour contrast is a less important issue.

Each chart: 10 points for each chart
    - 2 points: What is the issue
    - 4 points: Why does this matter?
    - 4 points: How to fix issues

Total: 30 points


Getting Started


  Review the notes
  Look at the chart critically
    
      What does the title indicate the chart is trying to show?
      Do the labels match the content?
      Is there a legend?
      Are the X and Y axis labelled (are they correctly labelled)?
      Do the numbers add up? (Do the numbers mean anything?)
    
  
  Review the data associated with the charts
    
      Does the chart match the data?
    
  


Here is what this might look like

Building better charts

    - 4 points for labels/titles
    - 6 points for construction
    - 5 points for explanation¬†

title: Examples
content:
Example projects

Small stories


  Daily(ish) stories
  Quick turnaround
  Fast data analysis, simple charting (built with existing charting tools - Google Charts, DataWrapper)
  work with existing (or just made available) data (from StatsCanada, etc.)
  Example stories/topics:
    
      stock prices
      employment/unemployment numbers
      crime stats
      housing data: Toronto area home sales fall to 10-year low in 2018 as number of listings dip
      polling data
      Dinesafe inspection data
    
  


Canada‚Äôs heavy crude hits record low as oil patch troubles intensify


  Oil numbers story
  Chart with single variable








Medium stories


  Some advance work (or: advance work that enables quick turnaround when data is released)
  Turn around time is measured in weeks (not months)
  Some charts (possibly custom charting), custom maps
  Examples:
    
      Cannabis stocks took over the TSX in 2018. This chart proves it
      A Better Way To Think About December‚Äôs Jobs Numbers
      These are all the places Ontario Liberals were beaten on election night
    
  



Census 2016: Western provinces‚Äô populations are the fastest-growing in Canada







Long-term (big) stories


  Can include filing and process access to information requests (ATIP/FOI)
  Scrapping, compiling, and analyzing data
  Can include building custom interactive features (see ‚ÄúWill the police believe you?‚Äù lookup feature)
  Major investigations, long-term commitment from reporting and data staff
  Examples:
    
      How BuzzFeed News Used Betting Data To Investigate Match-Fixing In Tennis
      Panama Papers
      Oil patch fails to clean up growing stockpile of abandoned wells
      What Went Wrong (Miami Herald/Steve Doig)
      WaPo police shootings database
  
      Trump‚Äôs Lies
      Trump Fact Check - database
      ProPublica‚Äôs Machine Bias
    
  


Unfounded: Police dismiss 1 in 5 sexual assault claims as baseless



More examples


  Dear Mona
    
      Mona @ the Guardian
      Mona‚Äôs podcast, Fortune Favours the Bold
      Mona Chalabi: How many women have been nominated to be US president?

title: Glossary of terms
content:
## Glossary of terms


### Outlier

__Outlier:__ one of these things is not like the other ones

___Explain___ something is askew



### File types

__CSV:__ comma-separated values
__TSV:__ tab-separated values

___Explain___ ... we save spreadsheets without all that whitespace. TK.



### Pivot Tables

__CSV:__ it's a table
![Pivot Table](img/pivot-lol.gif)
___Explain___ ... in a spreadsheet ... used for analysis

## Terms

### File formats

__CSV, TSV__
	- file types
	- comma- or tab-separated values

CSV data might look like this (in a text editor):

```
name,gender,major_minor,type,cause,,first_episode_title_text,,last_episode_title_text,seasons_array
Heather Brooks,female,major,intern resident,"['Electrocution', 'Brain bleed']",,Old Time Rock and Roll,,Old Time Rock and Roll,['12']
Henry Burton,male,major,family,"['Internal bleeding', 'Tumor', 'Diabetes']",,17 Seconds,,17 Seconds,['2']
"Denny Duquette, Jr.",male,major,patient,['Congestive Heart Failure'],,You Haven't Done Nothin',,You Haven't Done Nothin',['13']
Ellis Grey,female,major,family,"[""Alzheimer's disease"", 'Heart condition']",,Suicide is Painless,,Suicide is Painless,['6']
Lexie Grey,female,major,intern resident,['Plane Crash injuries'],,Dark Was the Night,,Suddenly,['8']
Susan Grey,female,major,family,"['septic', 'toxic megacolon', 'hiccups']",,All By Myself,,All By Myself,['5']
George O'Malley,male,major,intern resident,"['Bus crash injuries', 'Brain death', 'Internal injuries']",,Suddenly,,Suddenly,['8']
Charles Percy,male,major,intern resident,['Gunshot wound'],,Dark Was the Night,,Suddenly,['8']
Derek Shepherd,male,major,attending,"['Car accident injuries', 'Brain death']",,Invest in Love,,Invest in Love,['6']
Mark Sloan,male,major,attending,"['Plane crash injuries', 'cardiac tamponade', 'Coma']",,Perfect Little Accident,,Go Big or Go Home,"['6', '14']"
```

When opened in Google Spreadsheets or Excel, that data will look like this:

![https://cl.ly/f5ae1b991f46](https://d3vv6lp55qjaqc.cloudfront.net/items/0f301e2C191E1M373p1M/Image%202018-12-27%20at%204.12.49%20PM.png?X-CloudApp-Visitor-Id=c1693d93b1996b2027c04ee6dfa73c11&v=afe63322)

### Types of data
- CSV

### Tips for navigating your computer
-



### Number stuff

__Mean/average:__ If we get the sum of all values divided by the number of observations.

_Finding the average test score._
Scores: `76, 87, 78, 78, 91, 12, 67`
Add up all values: `76 + 87 + 78 + 78 + 91 + 12 + 67 = 489`
Divide this total by number of values: `489 / 7`
Average test score: `69.86`



__Median:__ If we sort the data, then find the value in the middle.

_Finding the median test score._
Scores: `76, 87, 78, 78, 91, 12, 67`
Scores sorted: `12, 67, 76, 78, 78, 87, 91`
Middle (median) score: `78`



__Mode:__ The value that occurs most frequently in the data.

_Finding the most common test score._
Scores: `76, 87, 78, 78, 91, 12, 67`
Scores sorted: `12, 67, 76, 78, 78, 87, 91`
Median score: `78`

	* The middle value in a set of ordered values.

title: Working with VLOOKUP ‚Äî SOLUTION
content:
## SOLUTION

- **Question** Which of the highest grossing touring artists from 2018 **also** made the list of highest attendance at a show?
- **Answer** U2, ...

### Step 1: Find and import the data.

**Step A.** Copy and paste the Billboard data. Split on the semi-colon. Correct the Shania Twain value. Rename tab to `2018_tours`.

![Import data 1](vlookup_solution/step-1-copy-data.gif)

**Step 2.** Use the `IMPORTHTML` function to pull in table data from Wikipedia (it is the second table on the page). The function should look like this:

`=IMPORTHTML("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_highest-attended_concerts", "table", 2)`

![Use IMPORTHTML to get table](vlookup_solution/step-1-get-table.gif)

**Step B.** When you use the the IMPORTHTML function, you are opening a connection between your spreadsheet and the website where the data table is live on the internet. In order to work with the data, you must remove that connection.

Option 1: Copy + paste special (being on the lookout for date formatting errors).

_Option 2:_ Download the data as a CSV and re-import the data. The advantage of this option is it is 1. usually pretty fast, and 2. is less likely to encourage errors in the data (specifically date formats).

![highest attended concerts](vlookup_solution/step-1-replace-data.gif)

Now we are able to sort, filter, and otherwise _use_ the data.

**Step C.** Correct the `Attendance` column.

We can now use the built-in `split text to columns` function to correct the Attendance column. Note: When using this function, whatever content is _to the right of your splitting character_ will be returned in the next column.

In our example: the data we want is in column F (Attendance), and the references/citations are in the next column (G). For this example, it's okay column G will be overwritten since we don't need the citations.

We will use the `‚ô†` character to split this column. The we will rename the column, and delete unnecessary data.

![split highest attended concerts](vlookup_solution/step-3-split-column.gif)

### Step 2: Check the data.

First, you should notice in your data about highest attended concerts is missing some data. Before working with this sheet, be sure to correct empty cells.

This is a good use case for two things:

Tip 1. Create a new column and populate it with a counter. This will allow us to put the data back in its original order after we sort and filter the sheet.

After the counter is created, we can sort a column (Z-A) to find empty cells.

![counter + sort to find empty cells](vlookup_solution/counter-sort-empty-cells.gif)

Tip 2. Using conditional formatting to highlight empty cells.

Once you identify the missing cells, populate the missing information. In this case, Oasis and Robbie Williams performed back-to-back dates at the same venue. We can copy/paste the missing values.

Also be sure to replace the `‚Ä¢` character (Edit > Find + replace). On Wikipedia, this character indicated the concert was the highest-attended of all time up to that point.

![conditional formmating](vlookup_solution/conditional-formatting.gif)



In order to use VLOOKUP, we need the fist column (column A) in both sheets to contain the same variable. In our example, we need artist names in the first column. Drag the columns to reorder.

![reorder](vlookup_solution/reorder.gif)

### Step 3: Data work

Create a dropdown menu that lists the artists from the highest grossing tour list.

![data validation to make list](vlookup_solution/data-validation-make-list.gif)

Then write a VLOOKUP function that looks for a match to the value (artist) in B2 (our dropdown menu of artist names).

This is what the function will look like:

```
=VLOOKUP(B2, highest_attended_concerts!A2:G25, 1, false)
```

VLOOKUP is a function that takes three parameters (or arguments).

The first parameter, `B2`: This the reference to the value we are looking for. In our example, we created a dropdown menu so we can easily look for a match without typing each artist's name. `B2` is a reference to a string value.

The second parameter, `highest_attended_concerts!A2:G25`: This is where we are looking for the artist (referenced in `B2`). In this example, we are looking in a sheet called `highest_attended_concerts`. We are then looking in a range of values, starting at `A2` and ending at `G25`. These two values are separated by an exclamation mark (`!`).

The second parameter, `1`: This is the index. When VLOOKUP returns a match, this is the column index of the value to be returned. So, if we want to return the name of the artist (the match), we use `1` because in `highest_attended_concerts` the artist name is the first column.

To return the number of people who attended that show, we would use an index of 7, for column G (attendance). üîó[Screenshot](https://cl.ly/36b29e53aed0/annotate)

![VLOOKUP](vlookup_solution/writing-the-vlookup-function.gif)

We can look through the options in the dropdown for matches. __U2__, for example, had a highest attended show, and a highest grossing 2018 tour.

However, while __Ed Sheeran__ made $429,491,502 touring in 2018, he does not have a "highest attended" show. His name returns an `N/A` error.

![no match](vlookup_solution/no-match.png)

While this `N/A` error is fine, we can wrap our function to produce a nicer, cleaner result.

We can wrap the lookup function in another function that checks for errors and returns a boolean value.

This is what the function will look like:

```
=ISNA( VLOOKUP(B2, highest_attended_concerts!A2:G25, 1, false)
```

When there is an error, this function will evaluate TRUE. Otherwise, it will return FALSE.

![ISNA](vlookup_solution/isna.gif)

We can now wrap our error handling function in another function. We can use the `IF` to return the name of the artist if they are on the attendance list, and return a string of text otherwise.

This is what the function will look like:

```
=IF( ISNA( VLOOKUP(B2, highest_attended_concerts!A2:G25, 1, false)), "Not on the list.", B2)
```

![IF](vlookup_solution/isna.gif)

We can continue to wrap and build out this function to return other values from the same row.

For example, we can check that are artist is on the highest attended concerts list, then return the date of the show, the city, and how many tickets were sold.

This is what the function will look like:

```
=IF( ISNA( VLOOKUP(B2, highest_attended_concerts!A2:G25, 1, false)), "NOT on the list", VLOOKUP(B2, highest_attended_concerts!A2:G25, 3, false))
```

![Many function many retunrs](vlookup_solution/many-functions-many-returns.png)

### Next steps

What happens when there is more than one match? _For example, U2 is on the highest attended concerts list more than once._


#### More on VLOOKUP
[More than one match](https://www.ablebits.com/office-addins-blog/2017/02/22/vlookup-multiple-values-excel/)

title: Working with VLOOKUP
content:
## Using `VLOOKUP` to answer the question:

- Which of the highest grossing touring artists from 2018 **also** made the list of highest attendance at a show?

### Step 1: Find and import the data.

**Billboard:** [Highest grossing 2018 tours](https://www.billboard.com/articles/events/year-in-music-2018/8488851/touring-charts-year-ed-sheeran-tops-taylor-swift-beyonce)
**Wikipedia:** [List of highest-attended concerts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_highest-attended_concerts)

In a tab/sheet called `2018_tours`: Copy and paste the `2018 TOP 25 TOURS` data into a Google Spreadsheet. Use the `split text to columns` function to convert this CSV-ish data into a well-structured table.

![Split to columns](../img/vlookup-1.gif)

In a tab/sheet called `highest_attended_concerts`: Use the `IMPORTHTML` function to import the table of highest-attended concerts from Wikipedia. (You will need the `split text to columns` to correct the formatting on the `Attendance` column.)

![IMPORTHTML](../img/vlookup-2.gif)

### Step 2: Check the data.

**This is important:** In order to use the `VLOOKUP` function, the fist column of data (`column A`) in ~both~ sheets needs to contain the same variable (ie., the artist name). This value is our üîë (our unique identifier, our ID).

In a tab/sheet called `2018_tours`: move the `Rank` column one to the right. (So the artist names, our key, is in the first column).

We can also re-name the column headers for the `artist/act` columns so that variable is consistent in both tabs. We can use `artist`.

![Rename columns](../img/vlookup-3.gif)

### Step 3: Data work

In a new tab (call it `data_work` or something similar): Use `data validation` to create a dropdown menu that lists the artists from the highest grossing tour list (tab/sheet name: `2018_tours`).

* In cell `B2`
* Open the data validation modal: Go `Data > Data validation`
* Under `Criteria` > select `List from a range` > then select the column of artist names `2018_tours!A2:A100`
* This will create a dropdown list in the cell.

![Split to columns](../img/vlookup-4.gif)

In `data_work`: write the `VLOOKUP` function to compare the value of `B2` with the value of any cell in `column A `in `highest_attended_concerts`.

* In cell `B3`
* Write the `VLOOKUP` function:

```
=VLOOKUP(search_key, range, index, true_false)
```

**search_key**: what we want to look for: a value, or a reference to a value.
    - `B2` (the cell with the dropdown menu)

**range**: where we are looking for the value
    - `highest_attended_concerts!A1:E100`
    - the sheet (`highest_attended_concerts`), `!`, and the range (`!A1:E100`)
    - always select the full range of data
    - we are selecting from the first cell in the top right to beyond the last cell of data in the last column - `E100`

**index**: which column to return
    - `1`: the first column (the name of the artist)
    - `5`: the attendance at that show

**true_false**: true/false if the data is sorted
    - `false`

...all together:

```
=VLOOKUP(B2, highest_attended_concerts!A1:E25, 1, false)
```

If you see `#N/A`, the lookup function did not return a match. When you see an artist name, that is the match.

![Split to columns](../img/vlookup-5.png)

We can update the `index` value to return the name of the tour, the number of people in attendance, or any other value from the attendance list. (Hint: when looking for a match, start with some of the ~older~ artists. You should find two matches.)

We can wrap the lookup function in another function, to return the name of the artist if they are on the attendance list (`TRUE`), and return a string of text otherwise (`FALSE`).

```
=IF( ISNA(VLOOKUP(B3, highest_attended_concerts!A1:B100, 1, false)), "Not on the attendance list", B3 )
```

`ISNA`: Checks whether a value is the error `#N/A`.

`ISNA(A2)`

`IF`: Checks against a true/false statement, returns 1 or 0

`IF(logical_expression, value_if_true, value_if_false)`




| Review: what we covered |   |
| :------------- | :------------- |
| Split text to columns       | ‚úÖ       |
| IMPORTHTML function       | ‚úÖ       |
| Paste special       | ‚úÖ       |
| Data validation: create a dropdown list        | ‚úÖ       |
| VLOOKUP function        | ‚úÖ       |
| Bonus: VLOOKUP function wrapped in an IF function        | ‚úÖ       |

#### More on VLOOKUP
[VLOOKUP](https://exceljet.net/excel-functions/excel-vlookup-function)
[YouTube video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E7gQ-PgYkMc)
[VLOOKUP at Starbucks](http://www.excelcampus.com/functions/excel-vlookup-explained/)
[Google support for VLOOKUP](https://support.google.com/docs/answer/3093318?hl=en)
[ISNA](https://support.google.com/docs/answer/3093293?hl=en)
